course.subject: COMP
course.name: Discrete Mathematical Tools for Computer Science
course.description: Basic concepts in discrete mathematics needed for the study of computer science: enumeration techniques, basic number theory, logic and proofs, recursion and recurrences, probability theory and graph theory. The approach of this course is specifically computer science application oriented.
course.prerequisites: A passing grade in AL Pure Mathematics/AL Applied Mathematics; OR level 3 or above in HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1/M2
course.corequisites: MATH 1012 OR MATH 1013 OR MATH 1014 OR MATH 1020 OR MATH 1023 OR MATH 1024
course.exclusions: COMP 2711H, MATH 2343

reviews.author: L.K.
reviews.title: 内卷严重但是很值得学的一门CS课（A very useful and very competitive CS course）
reviews.comment_content:
--- Before Midterm ---

Part 1 - Logic：
  逻辑运算符、逻辑等价、逻辑推理等
Part 2 - Sets and functions：
  集合与函数与不可数集
Part 3 - Number theory：
  带余除法、同余数关系、密码学基础等
Part 4 - Algorithms：
  算法基础（Big Theta, Big Oh, Big Omega）
  最坏分析，以及常见算法。

--- After Midterm ---

Part 5 - Induction and recursion：
  a. 归纳法（强归纳与弱归纳）
  b. 递归证明（结构归纳法）
  c. 递归定义（集合、字符串、二叉树）
Part 6 - Counting：
  排列组合、鸽笼原理、二项式、排容原理等
Part 7 - Probability：
  概率、条件概率、贝叶斯定理、随机变量等
Part 8 - Graph：
  有向／无向图、欧拉回路、欧拉路径等

reviews.author: solarski22
reviews.title: Hard exams and bad grades in spring.
reviews.comment_content:
Satisfying and interesting content. In terms of content, this course is good. It contains some math and CS stuffs, will be quite hard for people like me who are not good at maths.

Logic
Inference and proofs
Sets and functions
Number theory
Cryptography
Algorithmic analysis
Induction and Recursion
Counting, permutations and combinations
Binomial coefficients
Inclusion-exclusion Principle
Probability and Random variables
Graph Theory
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Yi teaches quite well. Not boring, sometimes even interesting. However, some of the points he gone through was not deep enough, he might just use a simple example to explain sth that will be much more complex when it is in the exam. His ppt slides are sometimes too simple. He explained some complex stuffs quite well, and he is kind and nice to answer your questions. One more point, he sometimes write notes on his slides on his iPad, but his handwriting is a bit messy, his writings will overlap with the words on the slides and he will erase part of it to further explain sth else, which is hard to read/understand, sometimes you have to rewatch the video to understand what he is talking about. Overall, his teaching is good.

The TAs are wonderful. They are helpful, nice, and are able to teach well. All TAs this year are very good. Sometimes if you got questions about your hw, you can feel free to email them and discuss with them, they can offer you good explanations. They did really well this year. FYI there are 5 TAs and they will each be responsible for 2 to 3 tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
For spring semester, if you are Y1 student or you have not got a major yet, then I strongly advice you to take this course later, otherwise, your CGA will have a lot of uncertainties, esp if you are are not very good at maths...

If you are a math genius, then just take any course you want, you don't have to care the grading part & this review.

THE EXAMS ARE REALLY REALLY HARD. You cannot imagine how the knowledge learnt in class can be applied to some of the questions. The logic flow of those questions are hard to follow, especially for year 1 students, the exams are definitely not the ones you encountered in MATH 1013/1014... Btw the pre-requisite is not accurate, MATH 1013/4 don't help much here.

Homework 20%
Mid-Term Exam 30%
Final Exam 50%

The Homework part is not very difficult, and you should try your best to get as high marks as possible in you homework. However, even if you could score full marks in your hw, it means nth to the exams, as the exam questions are a lot harder than the hw questions. This situation is not that significant in the midterm but very severe in the final. Every question is like bonus level. I heard someone else saying that the final questions are harder than 2711H in fall (absolutely harder than 2711 in fall too), you can take a look at them in the attached files below. I personally agree with it.

my stat:
Midterm: Touch mean
Final: 10 marks lower than mean (over 100)
HW: only one HW is below mean, others are nearly full
Grade = C range
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework + Revision/understanding + Do past paper
The workload is not too big, but not small either.
Adequate for a 4 credit course.

reviews.author: HakkaEason
reviews.title: a course which clearly shows that understanding concepts and solving problems are different.
reviews.comment_content:
Those concepts themselves apart from a few are quite simple and interesting (and some seems familiar as some of the DSE ICT and Maths topics), you can understand all of them in 2-3 days by doing revision (premise: if you have listened to all the lectures and seen those lecture notes). However, understanding those concepts is just the beginning. COMP2711 is really about manipulating problems until you can solve them using the concepts you were taught in class.

Also, understanding concepts ≠ able to solve everything. Try solving previous problems to get familiar with the "ideas" is the main point.
So basically the process would be like this:
understand concepts -> practice solving problems -> deal with those questions in exam papers
Topics:
Before midterm:
1. Propositional Logic, Predicate Logic, Inference and Proof
2. Sets and Functions
3. Counting, Permutations and Combinations, Binomial Coefficients
4. Inclusion and Exclusion
5. Conditional Probability and Bayes’ Theorem
After midterm:
6. Expectation and Variance
7. Number Theory and Modular Arithmetic
8. GCDs, Congruences and The Chinese Remainder Theorem
9. Cryptography
10. Algorithms
11. Induction
12. Recursion
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Leung (nickname: Kenneth) is already doing well at teaching, explanation with details on examples and proofs, willing to answer students' questions, also he did extra stuff so that we could have more questions to practice.
And there is very frequent interaction in our telegram group as there are TA and (very smart and knowledgeable) students always discussing some difficult problems, even some advanced problems. And they always answer our questions which really help us to understand how to solve those problems.
reviews.comment_grading:
I have heard that grading is a bit bad, like C range for mean in the past, but hopefully they would be more lenient in this sem.

Zoom Polls (10%) : 16/16
counts best 2/3 of polls (e.g. 24 polls in total then count best 16 polls).
1 mark for each poll, 0.5 mark for the wrong answer, 0 mark for not answering.
one poll for each lecture, so you can treat it as "attendance".
polling questions are actually very easy.

Midterm (25%): 21/50 (below about 1sd)

Written Homework (25%): 468/500
counts best 5/6 of HWs (6 HWs in total).
homework mainly test your basic knowledge of those concepts and test your solving ability.
In fact, most of the solutions to those questions in hw can be found online, you can double-check your answer with it.

Final Exam (40%): 42/80, above mean(40.9) a little bit

Total: 65.X% (mean about 68.X%)
Grade: B-
7X% should be B
A cut off at about 84~85%
the grading seems more lenient to low grade, might be increased 0.5~1 subgrade by comparing to previous grading, but high grade e.g. B+ or above seems still need to get 78% or above to secure.
reviews.comment_workload:
Each Homework may need 2-3 days to finish if you want to get a high score securely.
Doing revision isn't very hard and time-consuming. But make sure you have understood all the concepts, proofs, theorems (they are very important to remember as mostly they would be the key for you to do proving and solving) and examples(such as Monty Hall Problem and Towers of Hanoi, sometimes they would adjust those examples and put them into exams)
For the exams, I highly recommend doing every exercise and past paper they have provided. As you don't know how to do those questions because:
1. Some of the questions are mixed topics, you might not know how many/which concepts you need to use.
2. Sometimes you have to "guess" those questions, such as while doing a combinatorial proof or doing an induction step, you have to know what is the question saying and what the question requires you to do.
3. New question type is the biggest problem as you might have never seen it and have zero experience with it.
Therefore, you have to do a lot of exercises to improve your solving and understanding abilities, also for you to experience different kinds of questions so that you would have similar ideas with similar questions in the exam.

It would be a hard time for you a few days before the exam, as you would do a lot of papers, exercises and questions. Most of the time you would have brainstorm while solving those problems you don't understand and are not familiar with.

And btw, I recommend taking COMP2711 in fall better than in spring. In spring, there will be keener competition and harder difficulty in exam papers

reviews.author: Alexwww
reviews.title: BE SURE TO DOUBLE CHECK AND TRY TO EXPLORE THE BEAUTY OF COMP2711
reviews.comment_content:
Propositional logic

Counting

very useful topics and you can find some of them really inspiring and interesting
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Yi Ke is from mainland China but his English is fluent. He is patient to take questions and reply to all the e-mails so he is a good instructor overall. Even though I am not good at this course I am still grateful for his teaching. Although I kind of F off both exams and found it a relief not having 2711 anymore, I would still say that going to the office and discuss with Prof Yi has helped me get a better insight into those materials. He is always there to help answer our questions and it's really kind of him.
reviews.comment_grading:
For us, the grading scheme is 20% homework, 30% midterm, 50% final.
Just finished the midterm exam so cannot say much. The questions are not that hard if you are familiar with all the contents and being well prepared for reference (hard-copy) material (yes there is no online material allowed and I didn't realize it until the exam day). The time is not sufficient for me, due to the poor preparation of materials and poor strategy. But it is always the case that you should seize every possible point. This course is not friendly if you are careless (i am careless :(().
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Oh, I am back commenting on the final. The final exam has two parts, again. They focus on the second half of the material, from induction to graph. They tend to have questions that require knowledge of several areas (e.g. graph combined with probability and expectation etc), so we have to make quick reactions to them. The time is tight for me again, and for us there are a lot of scores regarding the graph theory, which surprised me a lot. The mean for the 2 parts of the final is 31/52, 23/46, so the exam is not pleasant at all. However, for hard questions, you should not just quit them. Just writing some random stuff that shows your understanding can give you unexpected partial points!! I didn't realize this since I was pretty nervous.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not big theoretically, for there are only 6 assignments (you are expected to submit the answer as a single pdf file). However, I have difficulties digesting them so I did turn to its textbook for extra content and had spent a lot of time reading the course note. Before class, I strongly suggest that you preview the content or you might have difficulties understanding some challenging part of it, or you might not realize what are the real important contents, making your lecture time inefficient. Also, be serious to the tutorial questions as they are inspiring as well.

reviews.author: NaturalEthan
reviews.title: Instructor matters
reviews.comment_content:
Since it's a CCC course, the course's coverage is wide. It includes:
Basic logic
Basic modular arithmetic
Cryptography, RSA, etc.
Recursion and Induction
Basic probability: Expectation, Variance, etc.
Combination: binomial theory, etc.
Introduction to basic graph

Those knowledge is well applicated in the CS area and will be covered in advanced courses like COMP 3711. It's a CS required course. So try your best to learn this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor TAI, Chiew Lan may be not suitable for this course. She teaches with an unclear mind, shows little logic in her teaching.  I found it's much easier to self-study via the lecture notes than listening to her teaching. She wrote in a messy way, not to mention sometimes she seems don't understand what's the meaning of the lecture notes.
However, I'd like to give a thumb to Professor YI, Ke. I took some of his lectures around the corner of the final exam, and I found he has a clear logic and he can explain the knowledge in a clear, fluent and easy way. His writing well corresponds to what he is speaking. In the end, you will find that Professor YI taught more contents in a 80 minutes class than Professor Tai, and you will find it more interesting and less confusing in Professor YI's class.
reviews.comment_grading: Fairly speaking, the grade is strict, but not fierce. You can view the grading scheme in other users reviews, and what I want to suggest is that you should digest the tutorial and lecture notes well, and do the past paper as much as possible.
reviews.comment_workload: Medium I think. There are 6 homework. They are inspiring. Take the homework seriously.

reviews.author: Argen
reviews.title: Depends on the Instructor
reviews.comment_content:
Just like the title, Discrete Math for Computer Science.

If you are Engineering/Science/Math student, you will find some of the content similar to other courses (e.g. counting and probability are very basic), while some of them are designed for CS students only, like modular arithmetic (mod, gcd, RSA), algorithm analysis using big O/theta/omega. Not very difficult if you have a good Math background and are familiar with their proof.

The detailed topics:
Logic (Proposition/quantifier)
Proof (Direct/contraposition/contradiction)
Set and function
Modular arithmetic
Counting
Probability
Algorithm analysis
Induction
Recursion
Graph
reviews.comment_teaching: TAI, Chiew Lan is my lecturer this semester. I would say she teaches quite badly. She expects students already having the knowledge (though some are true) and she just reads out from the powerpoint. Basically we learnt nothing in the lecture. She lacks preparation to the lecture notes, which leads to her "lagging" for a couple of minutes for the examples in class. She is an interactive lecturer, who asks challenging questions BEFORE teaching the main parts, and usually causing dead air for another couple of minutes throughout the class.
reviews.comment_grading:
This semester is a disaster.

Midterm is unexpectedly simple. Many students just get a full mark and the instructor claims "they deliberately do that and 80% of the final questions will have the same difficulty". Happily, the final exam reverses the difficulty, only 20% questions are like easy, while 80% questions are complicated or proofing with harsh marking scheme.

The TAs (especially mainlanders) tends to KILL you rather than giving you a good grade. For multiple times in the quizzes and final I have written for more than 15 lines (reasonable and logical, but some mistakes at the middle) for proving and eventually get a ZERO and comments like "WHAT?", "WHY?", "???" neglecting all the remaining part where I'm 100% sure correct.
reviews.comment_workload:
(For 2017 Fall only, because the course keeps changing and this may not be a good reference)

Pretty light.
1 midterm 1 final.
No assignment.
Weekly quiz with question pool provided. (For another lecture, biweekly quiz)
Inclass exercise

reviews.author: sgargaa
reviews.title: Good course
reviews.comment_content: There are 5 chapters that are tested in the final examination for this course. The first chapter is about the logic gates, sets, relations and functions. The second chapter is permutations and combinations. The third is about probability, which includes many theorems like Bayes' theorem etc. The fourth chapter tests cryptography and many other concepts about the same topic. The fifth and last chapter deals with concepts like mathematical induction. The highest weightage in the examinations is given to chapters 3 and 5.
reviews.comment_teaching: DYY is an excellent teacher and he uploads videos of his courses within 2 days. He teaches all concepts well and spends a good amount of time in class clearing the doubts of students.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is a bitch. The exams are pretty tough, yet the mean goes high.
10% assignments
30% midterm
60% final
reviews.comment_workload: There isn't much workload. 5 assignments in total. To be submitted once in every 2 weeks.

reviews.author: {Curly Braces}
reviews.title: Course with very Interesting Contents
reviews.comment_content:
The contents include:
1. Logic
  - Propositional Logic
  - Predicate Logic
  - Inference
2. Sets and Functions
3. Counting and Probability
  - Sum and Product Rule
  - Permutations, Combinations and Derangement
  - Binomial Coefficients and Binomial Theorem
  - Inclusion-Exclusion Principle
  - Probability and Conditional Probability
  - Bayes' Theorem
  - Expectation and Variance
4. Number Theory and Cryptography
  - Modular Arithmetic
  - Congruences and GCD
  - Chinese Remainder Theorem
  - Cryptography (Caesar/Affine Cipher, RSA Encryption)
5. Algorithm Analysis
  - Big-Theta, Big-Oh and Big-Omega Notations
  - Induction and Recurrence

Note that the graph theory is not included in this semester since there is not enough time.

To be honest, the contents of this course is quite interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching:
This semester is actually the first semester for Prof. Papadias teaching this course. Despite having a heavy accent, I personally like his teaching style, which makes me feel like watching a Youtube tutorial on Discrete Maths (but with interactions, of course).

Other than that, he teaches well and often ends the lesson early. He also makes quick responses to students for any questions, too.

(I skipped most of the tutorials so I cannot comment about the TAs lmao)
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
Homework: 30%
Quizzes: 15%
Polls: 10% (Counts the best 2/3 of the polls only)
Final Exam: 45%

This course is pretty much hard to get A-range for normal students since there would be some more big-brain students. Other than that, the grading is quite fair.

For reference:
Homework: 100% (All 5 homework got 100/100)
Quiz 1: 10/10
Quiz 2: 8/10
Polls: 100% (Got 15 of them correct, and there are total 22 polls)
Final Part 1: 17.25/30
Final Part 2: 20.5/30

Final Grade: B+ (81.8%)

As expected, the part the determine your grade the most is the final exam. I am just about 2-3 marks higher than mean for both parts of the final exam, which results in getting a B+.
reviews.comment_workload:
As mentioned in the Grades part, there is 5 homework to do in this semester, each of them consists of 5~6 questions. Each of them has some question that is challenging and may need some more time to think.
(In fact, some of the homework questions are actually taken from past papers lol)

For the polls, just make sure to attend every lesson, as you can still get half marks for each poll you get them wrong.

The difficulty of the quizzes is fair enough. The best thing is that they do not require us to join Zoom meeting for the quiz. But this does not mean the quiz would be too hard!

The final exam was actually out of my expectation. I expect the paper would be very long, but it ends up with only 3 questions in each part. But this does not mean the final exam is very easy. If you are not careful enough you can still fail. Because of this, doing past papers are important to tackle these careless mistakes.

reviews.author: !gpa_god
reviews.title: CS101 - Discrete Matematics
reviews.comment_content:
1. Logic (propositions, predicates, inferences and proving techniques)
2. Set theorem and functions
3. Number theory (mod arithmetic, GCD and congruence, cryptography)
4. Intro Algorithm analysis (big-O/theta/omega)
5. Combinatorics (counting, permutations, combinations, binomial coefficients, inclusion-exclusion)

reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Yi's English is not too shabby and is quite easy to follow. His occasional chokes are pretty hilarious too. Jokes aside, he is able to explain complex ideas pretty well. TAs are pretty helpful too.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 20% (best 5 out of 7 homework)
Mid-Term Exam 30%
Final Exam 50%

There are 7 homework in total, with around 4-5 questions, ranging from easy to moderately difficult. The mean for most of the homework are quite high (around 85% per homework).

Topics for the midterm differs from semester to semester. For this semester it was logic, set theory, function and number theory. The midterm was manageable but I fucked up by not thoroughly revising the topics before the midterm. The mean of the midterm was 75.6%, highest was 99.5 (fucking hell) and the lowest was 22.

As for the final exam, since all the lectures for this semester was delivered through online, the final exam was split into two parts and between each part there were 15 mins for people to upload their answers onto Canvas. The topics were mainly focused on point 4 to 7 from the aforementioned content list. Needless to say, this year's final exam was HARD AS FUCK and the mean reflects it.

Final exam (pt 1):
Mean: 27.6/53
High: 51
Low: 0

Final exam (pt 2):
Mean: 26.7/47
High: 46.5
Low: 0
reviews.comment_workload:
I don't think there's much workload for this course. There were only 7 homework, which only the best 5 would be counted towards the final grade.

However, you are expected to spend some time to revise after lectures cuz the midterm and the final exam were WAYYYYYY more difficult than the homework. Don't get too cocky if you got 90% or higher for the homework cuz you will be screwed in the midterm or final exam.

reviews.author: Kabul
reviews.title: Elementary content, mind-blowing exams
reviews.comment_content:
There is a combination of topics in different areas of discrete maths. Most of them, except the cryptography and the algorithm analysis part, are not very computer science-oriented. You can treat this course as an extension of your high-school maths.

Topics included:
0️⃣ Introduction to Discrete Mathematics

1️⃣ Logic
      🔶 1 Propositional Logic
      🔶 2 Predicate Logic
      🔶 3 Inference and Proofs
      🔶 4 Sets and Functions

2️⃣ Number Theory
      🔶 5 Modular Arithmetic
      🔶 6 GCDs and Congruences
      🔶 7 Cryptography

3️⃣ Combinatorics
      🔶 8 Counting
      🔶 9 Permutations and Combinations
      🔶 10 Binomial Coefficients
      🔶 11 Inclusion-Exclusion Principle
      🔶 12 Analysis of Algorithms

4️⃣ Probability Theory
      🔶 13 Introduction to Probability
      🔶 14 Conditional Probability and Bayes' Theorem
      🔶 15 Expectation and Variance

5️⃣ Induction and Recurrence
      🔶 16 Induction
      🔶 17 Recursion

6️⃣ Graphs
      🔶 18 Graphs
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof PAPADOPOULOS had a heavy Greek accent but it was still largely intelligible. He mostly lingered around the basic concepts and intuition, suitable for math noobs like me. Most importantly, he's fucking charming, with his athletic body build and visually appealing beard. Guys plz go ahead and 食洋腸. Hehe~😋

In comparison, Prof WANG's class (which shared the same set of teaching materials) drilled down to the more pure-math aspect of the topics. I recommend Prof WANG's lectures if you're mathematically mature and would like to have exposure to more advanced content.

The only thing I'd complain about was the difficulty gap between the content taught in class and the exams. I believe most of us were not equipped to do well in the exams even we were given these questions banks and past papers. The exams this year were soooo different from the past.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment scheme:
✏️ 20% Quizzes
✏️ 30% Mid-Term Exam
✏️ 50% Final Exam

The final score on the quizzes will be calculated from the sum of the 4 highest scores out of these 5 quizzes. A number of in-class exercises will also be given and they will at most give you a boost of 1 sub-grade.

✏️ Midterm
Mean = 35.7/60
Max = 59.5/60

✏️ Final
Mean = 48.2/81
SD = 17.2
Max = 78/81

While the professor taught easy content in class, both the midterm and the final were on a completely new level of difficulty. The exams this year required the synthesis and integration of multiple topics and there were quite a few "intriguing" questions that were totally out of my expectation.

One question in the midterm asked us to combine the 2 logic statements given by the knight and the knave. Most of us habitually formulated the logic statement by using inference ("→"), which turned out to be wrong if we carefully thought about the truth table values. Another question asked us to give a proof that every natural number can be written as a unique product of an odd component and a non-negative integer power of 2 (in fact the question was written in a more sophisticated manner, combined with notations of sets, divisibility, etc). From what I've heard the median score for that question across the 2 lecture sections was 0. I believe the vast majority of us had no idea of what the heck that question was going on LMAO.

The final was not easy either. "Basic" stuff included binomial distribution, structural induction (combined with GCDs), and the recursive definitions of the nCr function and the set of complete graphs. We also have a bunch of "interesting" questions such as the sequence formed by the number of ways the 3x1 tiles could be placed in a 3xn board and the proof of its recurrence relations, and another question on what values of m, n for a bipartite graph to be a Euler path but not a Euler circuit. No more mechanical mathematical induction. No more mechanical proof of recurrence relations. All these were implicitly packed into another interesting and deadly questions. Have fun and get wrecked in the final exam.

I got slightly above mean in the midterm, +1.14 SD above mean in the final and averaged 90-ish in the quizzes. Overall I got around 77.7%.

💯 Final grade: A-

The grading is very lenient. I could still marginally secure an A-range grade even though I'd crashed the midterm.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload of this course mainly lies on the quizzes and regular practice on past papers and tutorial discussion questions. But this year while practices are necessary, they are INSUFFICIENT for good grades. The more important part lies in the thorough understanding and the ability to synthesize and re-integrate different topics.

reviews.author: gonpachirou
reviews.title: Better introduction to CS than COMP1021
reviews.comment_content:
A comprehensive coverage of discrete math topics. My personal favorite is number theory as I've explored it in a bit of depth during high school. A point worth noting, though, is that the second topic requires an ability to write proofs and consequently an understanding of the formal definitions of sets, functions, cartesian products, intersection, union, modus ponens/tollens etc. I spent most of my midterm revision reading about the fundamentals.

Syllabus & textbook chapters
• Logic
○ 1.1-1.3, 1.4-1.5, 1.6, 1.8
• Sets & Functions
○ 2.1, 2.2, 2.3, 2.5
• Counting
○ 6.1, 6.2, 6.3, 6,4, 6.5
○ 8.5, 8.6
• Probability
○ 7.1, 7.2, 7.3
• Expectation and Variance
○ 7.4
• Number Theory
○ 4.1, 4.3-4.5
• Induction and Recursion
• Algorithms & Complexity
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kenneth is a great teacher! Super enthusiastic during class and explains concepts clearly. I really enjoyed attending lectures and I think this was the only course in Fall for which I had 100% attendance.

Also happened to be a common core; it was a pleasure to have had the chance to nominate Kenneth for the Teaching Excellence Award.

This might not be the case for all semesters but Kenneth created a telegram group which became insanely active ~2 weeks before the finals due to people discussing questions back and forth. Although I have to say performance in the final exam hugely depends on the amount of personal studying and past paper practice you do, the community this group provided definitely helped clear some things like some algorithm questions.

Kenneth also gamified practice for the final exam. He went out of his way to create a website where students can create their own problems and exchange them with other students' (1 problem you create for 20 problems by other students). I only did 2-3 problems but due to the ample background most students taking this course had, they really aided my revision and also served as fun challenges!

Definitely take this course even if you're not a CS student :)

• Midterm Exam (25%)
• Final Exam (40%)

*Note: discussions after the Final Exam with the H students seemed to show that 2711H's exam was somehow easier than ours. Not sure how that was possible but, it is what it is.

Tea (my stats):
- Zoom polls (100%)
- Bi-weekly written homework (100%)
- Midterm exam (71%, lost 20 points in a combinatorics question T_T)
- Final exam (80%)

Final grade: A

Personally I had a good experience with regards to grading, but others seem to say otherwise so I'll leave it for you to decide.
reviews.comment_workload:
Manageable, probably less than other math courses like MATH1014 and MATH2111.

Bi-weekly written homeworks consist of ~2 easy questions and ~3 long proof-based questions. You can complete them in 1 hour, 2 hours if you had a bad day.

Revision for finals and midterms >> PAST PAPERS! Do as many as you can and you should get a decent grade!

The homework is a basic application of whatever we are taught during the lectures. Some homeworld questions can be very hard, but you could always ask the TAs to help you out.

The final was much much easier than the midterm (I feel like a lot of people just gave up after the midterm and didn't prepare that well for the final and thus couldn't score well).

I personally did not practice questions at all unlike what the professor recommended at the beginning of the class. So make sure you practice a good amount of questions, and you can easily get B+ and above.

reviews.author: DrainGang
reviews.title: Choose the correct instructor!
reviews.comment_content:
Math related to CS, some concepts are quite useful (Big-O, mod, RSA).

This course is very much about understanding the course material, hard memorization does nothing. Most of the concepts in this course are not TOO difficult to understand (will take some effort). However, doing the questions in the assignment and exams requires more than understanding the course materials, which is the reason why this course is difficult.

This course is also somehow a common core course, simply put do not even think about taking this course if you are not a CS/CPEG student.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Abysmal.

While her English is acceptable, the lectures are very boring and the lecture notes are often incomplete, skipping steps and making the notes very difficult to understand. Concepts are not described clearly and the examples used are far too basic for you to understand what is being asked, some types of questions will not even have examples for you to refer to, meaning you have to Google on your own. And the poor teaching quality is reflected in the exam grades as the mean for my session is significantly lower than the other 2 sessions.

However, since Zoom polls are part of the course, you must attend these lectures and waste 80 minutes of your life sitting there when watching simple Youtube videos on your own makes learning this course far easier.

Tutorials do not require attendance, and all the TAs do is just repeating the answers on the tutorial questions, which you can just do yourself.
reviews.comment_grading:
25% Homework: 6 homeworks, only take the score for the best 5. Quite difficult due to the poor teaching quality, luckily some questions have full answers online. Spend time doublechecking your work with your friends to make sure you got the correct answer since its such a big part of the course.

10% Zoom polls: 20 zoom polls, if you answer 10 correctly you get the full 10%. Some luck is required since its unlikely you will understand the lecture enough to answer questions during the same lecture. Mean for this is unknown but it's very likely that most people got all 10%.

25% Midterm: 5 questions, difficulty luckily is lower than the homework questions, but still high. Mean: 29/50

40% Finals: 8 questions, strong emphasis on the materials taught after the midterm, memorizing the way to do the RSA/gcd/mod questions is key because they are very mechanical. Mean: 40.6/80

Ended up with 2% above mean, and got a B, better grading than expected!
reviews.comment_workload:
For a 4 credit course it's quite good.

Homework don't take too much time to complete (some questions have full answers online), most of the time is just spent trying to understand the course materials due to the poor teaching quality. However since there are no big projects or assignments, workload is relatively low, with a good lecturer that explains well the workload for this course will be similar to 3 credit MATH course.

As for exams most of the time is spent doing past papers, which the course does provide graciously, doing them is very important as you get to try coming up with solutions to answers yourself, which you don't get to do at all otherwise.

reviews.author: K_manifold
reviews.title: It can ruin your GPA, or it may not.
reviews.comment_content:
Syllabus:
Logic, Set, Permutation, Discrete Probability, Number theory, Recursion, Algorithm analysis

Graph theory is removed from syllabus in this semester.

Logic:
rules of inference, De Morgan's law, proof strategy, mathematical induction etc.
- nothing too complicated
Set:
naïve set theory, basic set operation, inclusion exclusion principle etc.
- basically serves as a foundation for permutation and probability
Permutation:
permutation, combination, ways to put n indistinguishable objects into k boxes etc.
- some you already learnt in secondary school and some require memorisation and understanding
Discrete probability:
expected value, variance, indicator variable, Bayes' theorem etc.
- exam questions can be quite hard
Number theory:
modular arithmetic, Euclidean algorithm, Chinese remainder theorem, discrete logarithm, RSA encryption etc.
- not too complicated, this course mainly covers the practical and simpler aspect of number theory
Recursion:
tower of Hanoi, basic ways to find closed form of certain kind of recursive function etc.
- not hard, you just have to remember the techniques
Algorithm analysis:
big-O notation, complexity analysis, divide-and-conquer, loop, algorithm design (no dynamic programming) etc.
- personally I think it is the most challenging part, but you are expected to be a COMP student.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Papadias is a good teacher who tried (and succeeded) to teach well. He provided interesting problems to raise attention on lectures and illustrated the ideas well.

TA will do questions in homework on tutorial sessions, you can ask questions or choose not to attend.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are 5 homework, 2 quizzes, 1 final exam and >20 polls (for online lecture).

Grading Scheme:
Homework 30%
Quizzes 15%
Polls 10%
Final Exam 45%

Polls are quite simple, and only the best 2/3 (iirc) polls are counted in final grading.

Each quiz (conducted online, during covid-19) consists of 10 MC questions. MC questions can be very hard.

Average of quiz: 7.6/10

Final exam consists of 2 parts, each part has 3 questions. You are given 60 mins to finish each part. Some questions can be extremely hard. There are always a few people who manage to get full marks though.

Average for final: 32.9/60

Grading is not bad, but the competition is very fierce. Locals should expect to compete with mainland and foreign students who are very competent and hardworking.

Try not to miss any homework and revise well for exams.
reviews.comment_workload:
Each homework consists of 5 long questions, and can be done within 2 hours if you are reasonably competent.

Polls are done on lectures and you should complete them without additional efforts.

Workload mainly comes from revision if you intend to get a good grade. The competition is really fierce.

reviews.author: Tommy Li
reviews.title: Carefulness competition
reviews.comment_content:
The course is about maths, discrete maths to be precise. There are mainly 4 topics covered in the semester:

- Counting
- Proofs, Induction and Recursion
- Probability
- Cryptography and Number Theory

The content is quite interesting, like how encryption works (e.g. https SSL sometimes uses RSA to establish a connection) and probability (e.g. the expected no. of tickets we have to buy to win a mark 6). The techniques are useful for future algorithm course like COMP 3711. I believe the inequality version of the master theorem can be proved using the advanced induction technique taught in class, but I did not have the time to do so during my revision period. I did try to expand the general form T(n) = a*T(n/b)+g(n) recurrence (w/ the techniques taught in class) and compared the result with the master theorem.

The topics are not difficult and the course materials suffice for a suitable amount of understanding. The notes explain the concepts well in some details. However, I personally think the notes of the other sessions are more concise and good for revision.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kenneth tried to be funny. He always carries a smile on his face. :)

The teaching is clear. You can understand most of the materials after the lecture. The in-class exercise gives a good practice chance to know your own level of understanding of the materials. A little downside is, the learning atmosphere of the class is not that good and Kenneth only sticks with the course materials. It would better if he can arise our interest to the topic by giving more real-life examples or further readings.
(Sorry for giving a B. I wish to give an A but my grading scheme is not as lenient as Kenneth's :P)  

The TAs explain the pool question quite well, especially Abishek. They are willing to answer your questions too. It's great to have them in the course.
reviews.comment_grading:
Kenneth is well known of his lenient grading scheme, this course is not an exception. However, the grade DOES NOT SCALE with your ability.

TBH, I extremely hate the assessments of this course. They are as easy as ABC. You can get full scores in quizzes, midterm and exam as long as you pay attention to the lecture, and most importantly, BEING CAREFUL. The questions in the assessments are extremely similar to the in-class exercises or the pool questions given. You don't even have to think about the solution.

If you aim for an easy B range, or you are a careful person, this course is definitely a good one. Otherwise, consider taking other sections or even H-course, those would better reflect your ability in terms of grades.

All score statistics are publicly available. Sorry for not attaching them here as USTSPACE does not support uploading HTML.

My score:
Quiz 1: 3/3 (Mean: 2.553, SD: 0.597)
Quiz 2: 3/3 (Mean: 2.681, SD: 0.410)
Quiz subtotal: 10/10
Game 1: 5/5 (Mean: 4.725, SD: 0.760)
Game 2: 5/5 (Mean: 4.641, SD: 1.153)
Game subtotal: 10/10
Participation: 10/10
Midterm: 88/100 (Mean: 78.05, SD: 17.81) => 26.4/30
Final: 88/100 (Mean: 81.12, SD: 17.02) => 35.2/40
Overall: 91.6/100 => B+

I misread "or" as "and" losing 8 points in the midterm. Then, I misread "distinguishable" as "indistinguishable" losing 12 points in the final. I understand it is my own fault for not being careful, but what is the point if everybody knows how to do the problems and grades are distributed purely according to carefulness?

I thought I would get a B as I am only in about the 40 percentile in both midterm and final. Thanks to Kenneth's lenient grading scheme, it turns out to be a B+.

Note: The exam papers are different for different sections in 2019 Fall. This may be changed in the future.
reviews.comment_workload:
2012H is an 8-credits workload course with 5 credits
2711 is a 2-credits workload course with 4 credits (for Kenneth's class)

I am glad that I have chosen this course else I would be dead from the disastrous workload from 2012H.

Kenneth's section is different from the others. There are only 2 quizzes instead of biweekly/weekly quizzes. There is an extra component which is the gamification platform. You have to answer 5 questions and post 1 question for each round. But there are only 2 rounds.

The quizzes, midterm and exam are extremely easy which you don't have to put extra time for revision (although I did put quite a lot of time, the effort did not pay off). Attend every lesson, complete all in-class exercise (treat it as revision, not for participation score, 12 lectures give you full participation), then you are good to go.

and then you can get full mark for the games (well you also need to propose one question in each game)

Have in-class exercises to take attendance, but you only need to go half of the lessons

Don't know if doing more exercises really helps, because a high mark is just not high enough.

reviews.author: tk31
reviews.comment_content: The course is pretty easy in class but when it comes to midterm or final exam, you really need to be carefull.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is really nice with Greek accent !
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is quite unclear and is not based on curve or percent of your grade. I think it will base on the your absolute grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is nothing much but when it comes to the period for final and midterm, the sample for exam is quite much and you should do all of them to be well-prepared for them because they are extremely hard.

reviews.author: LOLOL
reviews.title: Kenneth's 2711 = take it
reviews.comment_content: Teaches you the simple discrete mathematics topics: logic, permutation and combination, probability, simple remainder theorems, inductions, etc... The course itself does not go too deep into the topics so the fair amount of studying for the class will get you good grades
reviews.comment_teaching: Kenneth is VERY VERY NICE if you want to take this course. He's pretty good at teaching but most importantly his grading is a lot more lenient than the other classes.
reviews.comment_grading:
For Kenneth (and Kenneth only) , the grading is as the following:
10% Attendance (attend half of the lectures and you get full)
10% Quiz (5 quizes with the questions released beforehand)
30% Midterm (Which areas will be tested were told eg. logic)
50% Finals (Which areas will be tested were told as well)
Mean for midterm : around 75
Mean for final: around 67
I got 93 for midterm and 96 for final, full for quiz and full or almost full for attendance and got an A+ in the end.
The material wasn't too hard so start studying one or two weeks before final and you should be good to go
reviews.comment_workload: Workload very small, now homework, just prepare for quizzes and exams and you should be good to go

reviews.author: davidsaur
reviews.comment_content:
This course is more of a MATH course than a COMP course tbh.
Pre-midterm covers high school counting, probability, simple proofs, and some basic discrete logic.
Post-midterm introduces less-familiar concepts such as recursion (and recursive proofs), cryptography, and number theory.

Topics: Discrete Logic, Counting, Proofs, Induction, Recursion, Probability, Cryptography, and Number Theory
Textbook: C. Stein, R.L. Drysdale and K. Bogart.Discrete Mathematics for Computer Science, International Edition, Pearson, 2011
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kenneth is one of the best COMP lecturers in UST I've encountered so far. He gives detailed lectures and is clear about going through new concepts and proofs step-by-step.
He's also a pretty generous grader (mentioned during class that 85%+ is A-range).
reviews.comment_grading:
- 10% In-Class Participation. This is based on in-class exercises where you receive full marks if you hand in your paper for at least 13 lectures (roughly half of all lectures).
- 10% Quiz. The best 4 out of 5 quizzes are taken into account and the questions are given out beforehand. Hence, you should be able to get full marks for this as well(?)
- 30% Midterm Exam (single-sided A4 paper cheatsheet)
- 50% Final Exam (double-sided A4 paper cheatsheet)
reviews.comment_workload:
Low workload imo:
- No homework
- Quiz every 2 weeks
- In-class exercises for participation
- 1 Midterm
- 1 Final

reviews.author: tanya18
reviews.comment_content:
TOPICS:
-Predicate logic
-Propositional logic
-Inference
-Set theory
-Functions
-Modulus Operator
-GCD
-Cryptography
-Permutations and Combinations
-Binomial coefficients
-Principle of Inclusion and Exclusion
-Algorithms
-Probability
-Expectation Variance
-Induction
-Recursion
-Graph Theory
reviews.comment_teaching: He explains very well. He makes you practice questions in class so that you have a brief idea of how the questions can be. He accepts all suggestions regarding classes very openly and also explains the doubts very clearly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Although the content of the course might seem easy but the level of questions can be quite difficult.
FINAL- 50%
-mean: 50
-sd: 22
MID-TERMS-30%
-mean: 75
-sd:21
QUIZZES-20%(one quiz every week)
7 best scores were considered for the grade out of 9 quizzes taken
Mean is B
to get A range , you need to be at least one sd above mean in the finals
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is pretty high since there is a quiz very week
Also you need a lot of practice for the exams
Only reading through the theory won't help
Practicing questions is a must
Regular revision is necessary otherwise you might lose track of the topics in class
There is no attendance

reviews.author: fooldic
reviews.comment_content:
The contents are divided as 6 parts.
1. Logic
2. Number Theory (mod/GCD/Cryptography)
3. Counting
4. Probability Theory
5. Induction and Recursion
6. Graph

All of these are foundations of computer science. As a non CS major student, I still manage to find these concepts quite handy and interesting.

The number theory part is hardest to me because of all those modular arithmetic stuff lol.

Counting and Probability is easy as it's similar to high school math (or MATH2421). But be careful on analysis of algorithm, the questions related to it can go wild.

Induction and recursion part is fairly straightforward. Proof by MI... find a formula for recursion... you name it.

The graph part is also another pain though. Pay attention to the theorems proposed in lecture slides, as 1 question in final exam asked about proof of relationship between edges and vertices.
reviews.comment_teaching:
His teaching is very dull and boring, sort of a common problem among all mainland professors I guess. Through the lectures, he just managed to go through loads of examples demonstrating the concepts he's teaching, so really not much to comment about.

Basically you can just read the slides on your own and do your self learning haha.
reviews.comment_grading:
Overall fair grading.
Quiz 20%
Midterm 30%
Final 50%

Midterm
mean 76 SD 21
I got above 0.7SD

Final
mean 50 SD 22
I got above 0.9SD

Overall B+

(Honestly I have no idea why the final score was so low lol, thought I answered the final quite well hahaha)
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light, only 9 quizzes throughout the semester, 2 questions each. The questions are similar (or exactly equal to) those from the quizzes' question pool, so easy 20%.
The rest are midterm and final, duh.

reviews.author: SamsonChan
reviews.comment_content: Basic concepts in discrete mathematics needed for the study of computer science: enumeration techniques, basic number theory, logic and proofs, recursion and recurrences, probability theory and graph theory. The approach of this course is specifically computer science application oriented.
reviews.comment_teaching: Clear and deep teaching. Has explanation for every steps of proof using power point slide
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good grade. Mid term below mean and final get a mean turns out has B+. The grading is compose of attendant,  quiz, mid term exam and final exam.
Mid-Term Exam 30%
Final Exam 40%
In-class Participation 10%
Quiz 20%
reviews.comment_workload: Quiz for every weeks, basically review the topics learned. No homework. Not huge workload in general.

reviews.author: http
reviews.comment_content: The course is easy for me because I have a good foundation on maths. If you studied M2 in HKDSE, then MI would not be difficult for you at all. The theories are easy to master if you practise enough.
reviews.comment_teaching: Raymond's accent may sound a little strong but he is really nice and he responses to email very fast. And he's scarily efficient, he sent our marks separately through emails only four hours after the final. His notes are very specific and the in-class exercises are very helpful. Most importantly, he gives out grade really generously. Strongly recommend registering to his course.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is very generous thanks to Raymond, I got my first A range grade through this course.
reviews.comment_workload: There are one quiz per week. Each quiz contains one pool question (which comes from the "pool", containing several questions from the past papers and the answers are given, so basically you just need to remember the answers to take the quiz) and one bonus question (which is also from the past papers, but you don't know the answer beforehand, but there's no need to worry about it because this is bonus). But I think quizzes actually makes it harder to follow the content since you don't need to fully understand the content to complete them.

reviews.title: Really good grade (all thanks to Raymond)
reviews.comment_content: The course is pretty hard for me because I don't have a good foundation on maths, and I didn't listen to the lecture very much, so I can't say too much about the content.
reviews.comment_teaching: Raymond's accent may sound a little bit monotonous but he is very nice and cute. And he's scarily efficient, he sent our marks separately through emails only four hours after the final. His notes are very specific and the in-class exercises are very helpful. Most importantly, he gives out grade really generously (also for COMP1942). Strongly recommend registering to his course.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is very generous thanks to Raymond, I didn't get above mean in both midterm and final, just as I thought I must get a C or even D (I knew grading for COMP2711 is a bitch), to my surprise, I saw a B in the end (thank you Raymond!), so the grading is way better than before (compared with the comments for the previous semesters).
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is low for a 4-credit course, there are one quiz per week (thanks to Raymond, there is no assignments for this course now, and I heard they are like hell). Each quiz contains one pool question (which comes from the "pool", containing several questions from the past papers and the answers are given, so basically you just need to remember the answers to take the quiz) and one bonus question (which is also from the past papers, but you don't know the answer beforehand, but there's no need to worry about it because this is bonus). But I think quizzes actually makes it harder to follow the content since you don't need to fully understand the content to complete them.

reviews.author: GK
reviews.title: MATH2711 Funcdament math for computer science
reviews.comment_content:
Several major topics:

1. Logic
Basically logics that you would have known even before you study this course. Remember to memorize the notations, which is the only difficult part in this topic.

2. Counting
nPr nCr , you probably had learnt out in secondary school.  

3. Probability
Quite advanced probability.  Some skills will be taught to make calculation easier.  However,it's still like you know it then you know it, you don't know it then you don't know it.

4. Remainder
Basic skill for encryption.  You will learn some method to compute it faster,  and you will learn how to decrypt message under standard RSA cryptosystem.

5. Induction
Based on mathematical induction, you will learn more advanced stuff for Big O calculation.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Raymond is an excellent professor especially if you are a local student.  He can answer you in Cantonese and make explanation to topics much easier if you find him out of class.
Lecture notes are perhaps the best in ust. Well organized and a good summary for you to write your cheating sheet.
Though TA are quite useless in this class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Detailed calculation can be seen in other post. This semester has weekly quiz and no assignment.
Both exams above mean 1sd and got an A. My friend midterm below 1sd and final above 1sd got B+. I think it is already very great.
reviews.comment_workload: No assignment. In return, weekly quizzes. The quiz is based on a pool question(80%) and a bonus question(20%). Pool question is selected  based on a set of 4-9 question with solutions given to you. Either if you recite the solution or answer it by your knowledge gains you full mark. If you don't understand the course material,  try to copy the pool question and you will understand it better. With these quizzes, you are forced to learn and recite the course material weekly. Thus final exam comes a lot easier to study.

reviews.author: FallingChris
reviews.comment_content: 課程共分五部份。第一部份為logic，就一堆符號ouput出true /false，不算太難。第二部份為counting 的方法，其實就是permutation combination那堆。第三部份承接上一部份為probability，就記一堆formula就好。第二與第三部份其實與math2411重疊頗多。第四部份教cryptography，會講到兩三種加密方法，原理，多留心一下就ok。最後是recursion，有提到一些binary search作例子。
reviews.comment_teaching: 感覺就照著notes讀，但notes還是頗不錯。課後問professor問題亦樂意解答。
reviews.comment_grading:
Spring sem 較多超班的人reg，普遍exam 分的mean都比較高
有一部份為bonus attendance，根據professor心情隨機抽堂take attendance。
reviews.comment_workload: 整個sem共10份assignment，花點時間做不算非常難，除了每份assignment的bonus question。Midterm 比final 輕鬆多了所以一定要爭取多點分。

reviews.author: abc1230
reviews.title: Easy contents but not easy to get a good grade
reviews.comment_content:
Discrete mathematics for computer science.
- Logics
- modulus
- Probability
- Counting
- Recursion ...

The content of thie lecture is all about the diescrete mathematics that used in computer science (that might be the reason why this course has the code of COMP). Although the course name includes mathematics, it is quite different from the math that we have done before such as interations or differenciation. The content is pretty interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Nevin Zhang's lecture was always great and I attended most of lectures (95%). He was always well-prepared for every lecture with enough amount of example questions to explain the concepts. Another good thing about him is that his English is relatively fluent than other professors and the pronouciation is fine. (You can clearly understand what he says even in the recorded video) Also, he is always welcome to the questions from students. He also gives class weekly homework, which is graded, and this really helped me to keep on track during the course.
reviews.comment_grading: I think it is little bit hard to a good letter grade even though the content is relatively easier than the courses with MATH codes. Although you get not-bad grade on your exams like 80 out of 100, there are always students who get almost perfect grades. It is better to try to make no mistakes during the exam. I think that is the only way you can get an A range grade.
reviews.comment_workload: There are weekly homeworks, one mid-term and final-exam. The weekly homework never took me two hours to finish except once. You just need to attend every class (the attendence can work for bonus grade) and prepare for the exams.

reviews.author: Pang.
reviews.title: MATH2711
reviews.comment_content:
CS discrete math
Logic, combinations, probability, cryptography (mod arithmetic, RSA algorithm etc.), recursion and big-O-notation.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very boring, which is of no surprise as it is a math course.

Attendance will be taken for the bonus system which is pretty much useless.
reviews.comment_grading:
No good
0.5 sd above mean for both MT and final -> B

Mean and SD is ~70-75 and ~20 for both. With this range you need to get at least >90 for A range.
reviews.comment_workload:
Weekly assignments (which only account for 10% wtf...)
They are generally not difficult, though a basic requirement of related content is needed, or else you will have completely no idea how to do it unless you have source to copy from.

reviews.author: 如若
reviews.title: One of the WORST course I have studied
reviews.comment_content:
There are five major parts in this course. They are:

Part I: Logic
Part II: Counting
Part III: Probability
Part IV: Cryptography
Part V:  Induction and Recursion

The contents are quite board, which involves calculations,  proofs, and induction.
reviews.comment_teaching: Poor. Bad slide design. Bad explanation and presentation. Around 100 students enrolled in the lecture section and in week 12/13, there were only about 10 - 20 students left.
reviews.comment_grading:
The worst grading scheme I have ever seen:

Assignments: 10%    (2 marks each * 10 assignments)
Midterm   40%
Final:       50%

The above grading scheme implies that no matter how well you perform normally, you will obtain a bad grade if you do not good in exams. I don't know why I needed to spend so much time to think and discuss with others on the assignment afterwards.

Statistics:
Assignment : Around 8%
Mid-term: Around mean [Mean: about 59; SD: about 18]
Final: 3x marks [Mean: about 5x]

Finally, obtained C.
reviews.comment_workload: Extremely HEAVY. Almost one assignment every week. Each assignment contain approximately 10 questions. Need a lot of time to think and discuss with others. Even if you have sources, it did not help much as half of the questions are new.  Spend such a lot of time but this did not boost your marks up even 10%. The only good thing to the course is just it allows you to bring a cheat sheet  for the midterm and final exam.

reviews.author: Tony JI
reviews.comment_content: Quite useless course with a bad grade (4 credits); I recommend you to choose Elec2600 (or Comp2711H) if your major is CPEG. But if your goal is to maxmize the credit then this is your best choice.
reviews.comment_teaching: Skipped all the classes so have no idea about the prof
reviews.comment_grading: I think the grade is not good... Just as a reference, I'm higher than mean for one sd in midterm and final, and finally the grade was B+.
reviews.comment_workload: Nearly no workload. There are assignments everyweek but all questions are simple and won't take a lot of time. But still, the exams can have very difficult questions so you need to think more while doing the assignments.

reviews.author: gossipgirl
reviews.comment_content:
The content is pretty good. Mainly 5 sections:
1. Logic
2. Counting
3. Probability
4. Cryptography
5. Induction and Recursion
Not very difficult. Might find probability questions to be difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching: I guess the way the course goes for you doesn't depend too much on the teaching. Practice is the only way. But yes, Nevin is a good prof and teaches well.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is pretty harsh, ~mean+1.5sd in midterm and ~mean+sd in final barely goes to A range.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is moderately high if you want to put in a good amount of effort for a good grade. Weekly assignments  2 books.

reviews.author: abhr
reviews.title: Not worth the effort if the course is not required
reviews.comment_content: Content covers basic counting, logic, probability, RSA algorithm, running time of algorithms (big O, big theta). Gets boring most of the time. If math is your thing, you'll enjoy the course in terms of content.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Nevin Zhang is a good professor, although he bores his students in the way things are taught. Maybe its the course content, not his fault.
reviews.comment_grading: Oh the papers are NOT easy. The stuff taught in class does not prepare for the papers. Nasty surprises lie ahead until and unless you practice well. The curve is harsh for this course. The course has a bonus system for answering challenge questions and attendance.  Although they say that the bonus might help you, chances are slim that you're close to the grade cutoffs. Of no use at all. In short the course requires too much of effort, and brains.
reviews.comment_workload: If practice is your way to go, that takes a lot of time. Lots of time as the past papers are extensive and endless, besides other book exercises. Weekly assignments exist as well.

reviews.author: Nataliéêè
reviews.title: COMP 2711
reviews.comment_content: There are five main topic in total. The first three are basically a review of past knowledge. The RSA encryption system is very interesting but the professor didn't go deep into that topic.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor was able to explain the problems very clearly  by using different examples and drawing vivid graphs.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair. ( about half SD above mean for each exam --> A-)
reviews.comment_workload: There were five assignments in total. Each had approximately 15 questions with a few difficult to work out. However, you only have to get 10 of them correct to get full marks for assignments.

reviews.author: vgvr
reviews.title: Don't take it unless you must
reviews.comment_content:
There are a total of five chapters- 1) Logic 2)Combinatorics 3) Probability 4) Number theory and 5) Recursion.

A lot of new concepts are introduced that are pretty hard to grasp. A lot of practice is required to fully understand the concepts. It is beneficial to revise the homework questions and solve questions in past papers before exams. It is important to be in track with the lectures as it is very hard to cover up once you've lagged behind.

The order of contents in the text-book is different and the types of questions given in the textbook is different from ones in exams and assignments. I didn't find it too useful.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor explains the concepts very well and uses examples to illustrate. There is, however, little to no interaction in the class. Make sure you are in track with the content taught in class as it is impossible to do assignments if you're lagging behind.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments (x5): 10%
Mid-term: 30%
Final: 60%

The questions in both assignments and exams are not MCs and require you to work out the question step by step. The questions are quite hard and slightly vague. It is very hard to know how to start solving the questions without a lot of practice.
It is important to score well in finals due to the large weightage.
reviews.comment_workload: The assignments amount to a lot of workload despite being just 10% of the grade. The questions in the tutorial are sometimes similar to the ones in the assignments and a few of the answers can be found by Googling. The rest, however, take a lot of effort and time. You can try e-mailing the TA if you're stuck in any question.

reviews.author: 別問我是誰
reviews.comment_content:
開頭教既野好淺 DSE Math 都教過, counting (C, P) 同 probability. 去到中期開始教 cryptography (modulus, RSA algorithm) 同埋 logic (主要教d 代表唔同 true, false 組合既 math symbol)。去到最後終極 boss, recursion/recurrence, 教關於 correctness, running time 既野 (e.g. T(n) = c * T(n/m) + d) )

值得注意既係呢課大部分內容o係 3711 都會再提及而且好有用，尤其最後 recursion/recurrence。
reviews.comment_grading:
MT: Mean 77.89 / SD 13.91
Final: unknown
reviews.comment_workload: MT 前既野非常簡單且入門，都係DSE Math d 野，而且份卷既題型同 past paper 極為相似 (甚至有幾條係一模一樣，所以一定要做足pp)。

reviews.author: ____w.era______
reviews.title: A MATH Course DIsguised As COMP
reviews.comment_content: Some discrete math which should be useful as COMP students, including logic, sets & functions, counting & probability, number theory, induction & recursion, and algorithms & complexity. The only minor thing is that graph theory is skipped this semester due to time constrain. Still a wide coverage though.
reviews.comment_teaching: Kenneth is the best professor I have met in ust so far. He explains his slides very well with examples and the lesson is interesting. He is willing to answer students' questions at any time with the telegram group. The TA and some students in the group are so active in answering questions and giving out more example to help us understand better. They are all excellent and the atmosphere is so good.
reviews.comment_grading:
Zoom polling 10%
Written Homework 25%
Midterm 25%
Final 40%

The grading is very good (maybe due to Kenneth's nice teaching), a score around mean should be enough to get B. For some reason, there are a lot of year-1 students in this session but don't be too happy as they end up taking a lot of good grades. The polling is easy and you should be able to get full if you have common sense. The mean of the homework is quite high so make sure to pay extra attention to them. Both midterm and final in the semester is easier than the pastpapers, while the final is wierdly easier than the midterm. Personally, I got full for polling, 499/500 for homework, 40/50 for midterm, 74.5/80 for final. An A+ with 92.2%.
reviews.comment_workload: The compulsory workload is really low for a 4-credit course, the homework is at most 2 hours of work and they are bi-weekly so nothing much to do. I would recommend at least go through all the tutorials and some pastpapers to get a better understanding. Some extra exercises are providedby Kenneth and from other classmates which is very helpful.  Finishing everything you recieved would be more than enough to get a good grade and it would only take about 4 extra days in your whole semester to do so.

reviews.author: ForeignerIvan
reviews.title: Provides very good maths foundation material in compsci and a great collaborative atmosphere
reviews.comment_content:
In order:
Logic (Propositional Logic, Predicate Logic, Basic Proof Templates, etc.)
Sets and Functions (Naive Set Theory, Cardinality, etc.)
Counting (Permutations/Combinations, Pigeonhole Principle, Inclusion-Exclusion, Binomial Theorem, etc.)
Probability (Bayesian, Expectation/Variance, etc.)
Number Theory (Modulo, GCD, Cryptography)
Induction and Recursion (Weak/Strong/Structural Induction, Recurrence Relations, etc.)
Algorithms and Complexity (Big O, worst-case analysis, etc.)

For me, most of the concepts were familiar enough since I learnt of them in secondary school, but I could see some students struggling with some of them in terms of computation, especially Probability and Counting. All in all, I think the syllabus provides a solid mathematical foundation in Computer Science.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Leung was an overall great instructor! He always motivated students to answer questions and ask questions in class, and used many concrete examples to explain abstract concepts. The visuals he used to explain worst-case analysis, for example, has really helped me understand. The Zoom polls let us check our understanding and Leung was always ready to clear up misconceptions as represented in the poll results.

The Telegram group he and other TAs had opened have created an open, supportive and collaborative atmosphere for us to ask questions and support one another.
reviews.comment_grading:
Zoom Polling: 10% (1 question for each of the 24 lectures, only counts highest 2/3 of them; also counts as attendance)
Bi-weekly Homework: 25% (6 in total, counts highest 5, 5 Qs each)
Midterm: 25%
Final: 40%
(Cheatsheets are allowed in both exams)

Midterm Stats:
Mean - 29.97/50 (SD 9.63)
Median - 30/50

Final Stats:
Mean - 40.9/80 (SD 16.3)

For me,
Zoom Polling: 10/10
Homework: 24.65/25
Midterm: 38/50 --> 19/25
Final: 71.5/80 --> 35.75/40
Total: 89.4% --> A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Zoom polling: very very simple, if you pay attention to class you should easily get a full mark.

Homework: the homework is not too difficult as they employ the concepts in the notes fairly simply (aside from one or two questions). I spent an estimate of 1-2 hrs doing the Qs and another hour typesetting in LaTeX (NOT required but I like keeping things neat).

Midterm: Difficulty is just about right, lost 10+ points only because I misinterpreted the entire question about probability ;-;

Final: Simpler than I had anticipated, all concepts are tested fairly simply and separately, only difficult part was algorithmic analysis where you have to write out algorithms having the right big O with pseudocode.

All in all, for both exams, only hurdle to A range is to practice more with past paper problems and supplementary ones the TAs had generously provided.

reviews.author: chk
reviews.title: Hard course of this semester
reviews.comment_content: I think it's too much to cover in one semester. But It's undeniable that some are content is useful for CS students, like Big-O, the use of modulo, as well as RSA encryption/decryption.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I will say the teaching of Prof. Dimitris is good, it's not very hard to understand. The lesson of Prof. Tai is really really boring and 830 lessons, it's hard to understand her words.

But remember there is a Zoom Poll, and professor Dimitris only you to do it with 1~2 mins, and some of the questions require some understanding of the lesson. That's mean you have to pay attention to the whole lesson, otherwise, you only able to get 0.5/1.0 participation. I don't the poll in other class, but I can say the pool in the lesson of Prof. Dimitris is really fast.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grade on this subject is really really bad. Actually, this subject is a well-known killing subject. My GPA does not rely too much on this subject.

Final Exam: 40%  Midterm: 25%  Homework: 25%  Polls: 10%
There is 6 homework in total. And they only calculate the final score based on the best 5 assignments you did. The assignment is not very hard but far from the difficulty of the examination.

And I did very very bad in the final exam and midterm. Both parts are below 2SD of the mean. I still haven't got an F lol. But it's a really hard course. I have done all the tutorials and redo all the homework before the week of the examination. And I still did very bad in this stupid course.
reviews.comment_workload: It's quite good for a 4 credit course. If you are good at doing an assignment, you can do the first 5 homework, and I took 2-3 hours to do 1 single homework. I think those who are reading my article can do this stupid thing faster than me.

reviews.author: holymama

reviews.comment_grading:
作為一個算係有數底嘅non-maths/phy/comp major嘅人，喺其他course都接近攞曬A range嘅時候，我迎接左我人生唯一一個C range, C- arrr btw :)

唔好以為自己係其他major，叫係有數底，一見到有 "mathematics" 嘅common core就衝出去讀，如果唔係就會變到我咁 :)

reviews.comment_workload:
對唔住係我錯, year 4先黎reg依個course

reviews.author: 落車請早揚聲
reviews.title: CAREFUL CAREFUL CAREFUL
reviews.comment_content:
The coverage is quite wide, including logic, counting, probability, number theory, cryptography, induction, recursion, etc.

If you are from mainland, then you should already be familiar with everything except number theory and cryptography. So the content is wide but not hard.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kenneth is a good lecturer and also a very easy going guy himself. He tries to be funny in classes, and is always willing to answer all your questions. Even this sem there was one "not very polite student" in the first few weeks, he still didn't get mad.

And as far as I am concerned, his English is better than the other to sections (Without a heavy accent)
reviews.comment_grading:
I really want to give this part an A, but I hesitated and gave it a B in the end.
Beacuse of the easiness of the content, I was really expecting an A or A+, but I only ended up with an A-.
Well, actually, I really thought I was getting a B+ before I saw the letter grade, cuz my overall percentage wasn't that high, so I don't blame to end up with A-. In fact someone who is 1% overall higher than me got A, so I must admit, the grading is lenient!
So you might wonder, why did I give it a B?

Because the assesments really test your carefullness. Almost everyone can get full in HWs and IPRS, what really determines your grade is the final exam and the quizes, which are quite easy. So carefulness become so important. I made 2 extremely stupid mistake in the final exam and in the 2nd quiz, losing about 3.%something out of the overall. I understand it's my own fault of making such kind of mistakes. but because the questions in the final exam really aren't hard, the mean gets high and sd goes down. Hence making careless errors can easily cost you subgrades. (which is my case)
SO,  BE CAREFUL!
reviews.comment_workload:
not high at all.

I would say this is a 4 cre course with only 2 cre workload

To be honest, because everything is learnt already except number theory and crypto, this course is the course that I spent the least time on in this semster....

reviews.author: Alex Du
reviews.title: Grading is bad, careful
reviews.comment_content:
Basic knowledge of discrete mathematics.

WITH A LOT OF IT MISSING.

This is a fall course, so no graph taught. no formal language taught. I just feel it difficult to understand why these contents are eliminated. If you want to learn the entire discrete math, please do not choose fall course.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is not bad to be fair. The professor actually explains everything in detail and he did his work.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is bad.
So basically this term there's hw 30%, polling 10% with the best 2/3 counted, quizzes 15% and final 45%.
My statistics, however, was full in hw, full in poll, 13/15 in quiz and 25/45 in final. I am a little bit above mean, since the mean is 24.75. And all I got was a B-. I do not consider it fair, since this shows that all my hardship in the regular works were torn down ONLY because of a bad final.
The final's grading is quite unreasonable. So what they do is: answer correct, deduct marks from the work; answer wrong, everything wrong. Cool? Best part of it is when you try to argue, they'd say "oh you know what? I discussed with the professor and we think you shouldn't get this mark. You wanna have know the reason? Sorry but no."
reviews.comment_workload: The workload seems to be higher than a regular 4 credit course. There is homework all the time, and you'll find yourself always dealing with homework.

reviews.author: 102938chi
reviews.comment_content: Basic concepts in discrete mathematics needed for the study of computer science: enumeration techniques, basic number theory, logic and proofs, recursion and recurrences, probability theory and graph theory.
reviews.comment_teaching: Great. But as far as I concerned, his lecture might be a little bit more difficult than the others in the same semester(Because students in other lectures said the content was easy but I didn't think so in WANG's lecture). He taught a lot of proofs and some questions set by himself but enriched the content.
reviews.comment_grading: Maybe because I did a bonus question, the grade is higher than I expected.
reviews.comment_workload: No homework at all. Only one quiz every two weeks, midterm and final. It's light for me.

reviews.author: ustjj
reviews.comment_content:
Discrete Mathematics as said in the course title, as computer can't handle continuous things.
Logic (T/F), Number theories, and then things in M1/M2 in HKDSE. I personally think that the content is quite interesting and easy.
reviews.comment_teaching: Decent teaching, not good, not bad. It's ok not to attend tutorials as the lecture slides explain theories quite explicitly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Better than expected. Long heard that this course gives bad grade in Spring, but perhaps not this semester.
98/100 in midterm, mean is 7x
7x in final, mean is 5x
Full in hw
Finally got A+
There is a bonus question for both midterm and final, and there will be potential one sub-grade up if the score in bonus questions is good.
reviews.comment_workload: Negligible. 7 HW with about 4 questions each, and doing it yourself is very easy)

the only thing you need to do is review before quizzes, no homework need to be submitted.

reviews.comment_workload:
