reviews.author: Gi Grade
reviews.title: Challenging but good grade course
reviews.comment_content:
- Logic
- Sets and functions
- Counting, Permutations, Combinations
- Binomial Coefficients
- Inclusion-Exclusion Principle
- Probability
- Random Variables
---------------------- Mid-term ----------------------
- Number Theory
- Cryptography
- Algorithms
- Induction
- Recursion
- Graphs

The final exam includes all topics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kenneth teaches very well. It is not boring when attending his lectures. Also, he has a good accent so you can understand what he says very clearly during lectures. Also, there are midterm review and final review before midterm and final respectively. During the review section, he will mention the key topics which will appear in the exam, so you definitely don't want to skip those.

The only thing is that the prof will say "Easy" for basically all topics, which is from his perspective the topic is easy. Basically, if prof says "Extremely Easy" then it is relatively easier, otherwise you have to be really careful since it would be quite challenging.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grading. Prof promised that he will provide a wider A-range if we do well.

Grading Scheme:
In-Class Exercise 10% (prof will provide the answer during lecture)
Homework 25% (count the best 5 out of 6)
Mid-term 25%
Final Exam 40%

My Scores:
In-Class Exercise 100/100
HW 93.8/100
Mid-term 80/100 (Mean 58/100)
Final Exam 72.5/100 (Mean 53.7/100)
Final Exam Bonus 10/10 (Mean 3.2/10, Median 0/10)

Even though it doesn't seem well but I still somehow got an A+, so I guess it should be a really wide A-range.
reviews.comment_workload:
6 homework, 1 mid-term and 1 final. Acceptable workload outside class.

However, in every lecture there is an in-class exercise, even though the prof will tell the answers during lecture, which is not difficult, that basically means that you cannot really skip lectures.

For tutorials, I didn't attend any of them, but I think doing past papers would be enough for the exams.

reviews.author: PAN,Haoyue
reviews.comment_content: Other people have told you the content so I don't need to talk more.
reviews.comment_teaching: Yi ke is a good teacher but the content in ppt is very different from midterm term and final exam! You will think "Oh it's so easy I really got it" in lecture but in exam, you will think "Oh what's that question? It is seem as questions in lectures but much more difficule. You will find that you seems know how to do it but you couldn't do it in fact.
reviews.comment_grading: It have in lecture quiz and time is so short that before you get answer, time has done.
reviews.comment_workload: For homework Ta use unreasonable grading  standard. Even though there are no instructions, you still have to do it the way they take it for granted. Any method that is reasonable but not part of the class will be deducted a lot of points.

reviews.author: Bob Zhou
reviews.title: Nothing to worry about
reviews.comment_content: The content is most learnt in the high school, but some parts ,eg. probability,  may be a little confusing for those who first meet them. However, if you work hard enough, which means taking all the lectures and making notes carefully, an A range is easy to reach.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor and TAs are quite nice and patient. You can write an e-mail to ask for any thing. Sometimes in the lecture the professor will expand a little, which is the most interesting part in the course.
reviews.comment_grading: Grade seems the most concerned part. There are some rumors that in the spring semester, the grade of the course is horrible. It's partly true that it's really hard to get an A+, but get an A is easy if you got full scores in your homework and never made stupid mistakes in your midterm and final.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is quite heavy. You will cost most of your spare time there. There are 7 homework costing about 3 hours each and you really need some time to review your notes and take pastpapers.

reviews.author: hiiluvpenguin

-logic (propositional, predicate, inference and proofs)

-Final Exam 45%

Yet, getting a good grade might require a certain dedication of time spent outside class to work on practice questions in the textbook by yourself apart from questions given in the quiz pool/ practise pool for a better understanding of the topic.

reviews.author: Carson Leung

reviews.comment_grading: The grading of this course is super good. For me, all my quiz, midterm, final are all around the mean, and I can still get B for my final grade, isn't that good?
reviews.comment_workload: You should bear in mind that the workload various among different professor. For Kenneth, the workload is really super low with no assignment. We only have one midterm one final 2 quiz with pool question and a gamification platform.

reviews.author: rray

reviews.author: mark_
reviews.title: Good course
reviews.comment_content:
Propositional Logic
Sets & Functions
Counting, inclusion-exclusion principle
Probability + Conditional Probability
Expectation/Variance
Number Theory & Cryptography
Algorithms & Time Complexity
Recursion & Recurrence relations

The content has a lot of applications in computer science when solving programming problems, especially more theoretical ones. You also get a lot of insight into how modern cryptography such as RSA works.

However, the problem solving part and applying these concepts may be difficult for some people not already acquainted with more rigorous maths, so keep that in mind.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kenneth Leung (the professor) teaches very well. He explains quite complex topics in quite a digestable manner and goes through a lot of examples to make sure you understand them. He also does one Zoom poll every class to make sure you are following. If you get it wrong, it's not a big deal (he only counts the best 2/3 in your grade) and it is a useful guide for what to practice at home.

If you need proof, our lecture session's mean was the highest out of the three and we had "quite a few A grades" (according to the professor) :)

Some of the TAs are very good and are very willing to answer questions and give you supplementary exercises. This semester, we had a group telegram where students could ask questions and get them answered by other students or a TA. The group chat was quite active this semester, which the professor said was quite unusual but good.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% In-class polling (count best 2/3, 20-24 in total)
25% Bi-weekly written homework (count best 5 of 6)
25% Midterm
40% Final

Extremely lenient grading this semester it seems.

You should get 100% on both the polling and homeworks because they are not difficult at all. The homework does take some time to do, however, so don't leave it till the last minute.

At the bare minimum, you should get 100% on the polls. It's a free 10% of the final grade.

The exams this semester are much easier than previous semesters for some reason. They seem to mainly test knowledge rather than problem solving skills and smartness (apart from one or two questions). However, the mean is still quite low.

So, if you are not too good at maths, don't take this course in year 1 and you're looking to get into CS, because this has the chance of tanking your GPA.

My grades:
Polls: 100%
Homeworks: 100% (100% on all 6)
Midterm: 37/50 (mean 29.97, median 30, SD 9.63)
Final: 62.5/80 (mean 40.9, SD 16.3)

=> 84.8% (A)
(someone else got 83% and they got an A- so it seems 84-85% is the A grade cutoff)
reviews.comment_workload:

However, studying for the exams is quite a nightmare. The workload is heavy if you want to study and master all the topics - the few days before the exam, I did practically nothing but study for COMP2711. This is why I rate the workload a B instead of an A.

reviews.author: wowww
reviews.title: Hard work can compensate everything
reviews.comment_content:
I think most reviews just offered info based on the course itself, without any context of the author, so I hope to briefly mention my background. Local student with math/M1 5**, 1013 and 1014 A, 2411 A-, not a big fan or talented in maths.

First half (before midterm):
Logic
Set and functions
Number theory
Algorithms

These topics are almost completely new to me, but some of them are quite interesting and thought-provoking. If I need to arrange them by increasing difficulty, it should be like this:
Algorithm<logic<Set and functions~Number theory.

Algorithm: basically just intro to algo, you just need to apply some knowledge from 1014, e.g. n!>n^2
Logic: just manipulating logical gates and inference questions
Set and functions: the questions to prove sets are countable/uncountable or having bijections are hard, you cannot practise a method to do the questions like the above 2 topics, you need to build up a mindset to do so.
Number theory: gcd and crypto, crypto questions could be practised, gcd questions could vary a bit and sometimes hard to deal with

Second half (after midterm):
Induction and recursion
Counting
Probability
Graphs

As a M1 students, the second half are easier to handle, especially counting and probability, difficulty is as follows:
Probability<Counting<Graphs<Induction and recursion

Probability and counting: mostly M1 stuffs with some new concepts, pigeonhole principle, derangement, but not really hard
Graphs: mostly definitions and questions are quite standard
Induction and recursion: personally think they are related but their difficulty should be ranked differently, recursion questions are much more harder than induction.

To all hkers:
You might think that my background is quite impressive but bear in mind there are lots of nds who have encountered most topics in high school. I am not particularly talented in maths but there are lots of resources for you to practise and you should try your best to finish them in the following order:

1. Past papers
2. Book exercise (supplementary exercise)
3. Book exercise (by sub-chapter)

I can promise you if the % of past papers and supplementary exercise you finish could reflect your final grade, if not equal to.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Yi Ke's accent is okay. As a HKer, I would not find it too difficult to understand his lectures. He also explains concepts quite clearly and he answers questions patiently after class/via email. But for some math concepts, he might assume they are basic/intuitive and just quickly went through. If you find you cannot understand the lecture content fully, you should find different ways to learn yourself. Here are some methods I used to improve my learning (arranged based on my preference):
1. rewatch the lecture recordings
2. youtube
3. read math/stack exchange posts
4. email prof/ask ta

reviews.author: Mayl
reviews.title: Simple and interesting course on simple maths
reviews.comment_content: The course content is about various topics in discrete mathematics in computer science. In other words, those problems that could not be solved directly by computers, but are essential in computer science. Actual topics include logic, proofs, combinatorics, number theory, modular arithmetic, probability, recursion, induction, graph theory and some other things. As you can see, the problem is that there are way too much topics for one course. As a result, each topics is very briefly covered, and a lot of more interesting stuff is removed. Also, since the pace is quite fast, you are recommended to have some prior knowledge or read some materials before the course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
As I mentioned, the course is mainly about prior knowledge and self learning, so there is actually no need to attend the lectures (the lecturer said that himself, I modified a bit). However, if you have free time, going to the lectures are quite fun. Prof. Wang explains things in a clear manner, and he mentions different interesting stories about each topic.
For the tutorials, it is basically about doing quizzes and checking answers. There is not much teaching, soo I do not have much to say.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is quite good. Basically, if you are good at mathematics (the thinking part, calculation is not important), you can get A range quite easily, provided that you do the exams and quizzes carefully. Even if you make some careless mistakes, there are bonus questions to save you. The grading scheme is 20% quizzes, 30% midterm, 50% final (each bonus is 2%, each bonus is either 0 or 100). Some statistics are provided below:
Quiz 1: Mean:80.6/100
Quiz 2: Mean:83.8/100 Bonus 1: Mean:3.2/100
Quiz 3: Mean:91.9/100
Quiz 4: Mean:79.2/100 Bonus 2: Mean:32.6/100
Quiz 5: Mean:76.2/100 Bonus 3: Mean:9.8/100
(Highest four out of five quizzes are counted in final grade)
Midterm: Out of 60, the mean is 36, and the first, second, and third quartiles are respectively 29, 34, and 46.
Final: Out of a total score of 81, the first quartile is 65, the median is 44, and the third quartile is 33.
Me: Quiz average: 91/100 Bonus: 2 out of 3 Mid: 60/60 Final: 78/81 Grade: A+
It is good to see that the A+ grade is attainable here.
reviews.comment_workload:
This depends. If you have enough prior knowledge on this course (like me), the workload is basically 0. The only actual workload is that I need to attend five quizzes. There is not much need for revision.
However, if you are not good at math and do not have prior knowledge, catching up would be quite difficult and the workload might be quite large,

reviews.author: zzhoho0110
reviews.title: 等D再補
reviews.comment_content:
Syllabus:
Logic, Set, Permutation, Discrete Probability, Number theory, Recursion, Algorithm analysis

Graph theory is removed from syllabus in this semester.

Logic:
rules of inference, De Morgan's law, proof strategy, mathematical induction etc.
- nothing too complicated
Set:
naïve set theory, basic set operation, inclusion exclusion principle etc.
- basically serves as a foundation for permutation and probability
Permutation:
permutation, combination, ways to put n indistinguishable objects into k boxes etc.
- some you already learnt in secondary school and some require memorisation and understanding
Discrete probability:
expected value, variance, indicator variable, Bayes' theorem etc.
- exam questions can be quite hard
Number theory:
modular arithmetic, Euclidean algorithm, Chinese remainder theorem, discrete logarithm, RSA encryption etc.
- not too complicated, this course mainly covers the practical and simpler aspect of number theory
Recursion:
tower of Hanoi, basic ways to find closed form of certain kind of recursive function etc.
- not hard, you just have to remember the techniques
Algorithm analysis:
big-O notation, complexity analysis, divide-and-conquer, loop, algorithm design (no dynamic programming) etc.
- personally I think it is the most challenging part, but you are expected to be a COMP student.

reviews.title: 4 credit course with very light workload
reviews.comment_content: A very beginner-friendly math course. Quite a lot of overlap with probability course, to an extent that you don't even need to pay any effort in this course in the first-half semester. If you would like to really learn the complexity of algorithms and the principle behind, I would recommend COMP2711H
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof WANG is a very kind and helpful professor. He has a very solid background in cybersecurity, so during his teaching, he would combine the abstract discrete mathematics with real application in security and privacy. He also included a lot of interesting examples in his lectures to facilitate understanding. And he guided students through some sample questions during lectures as well.

Also, compared with many other professors in science school, I would say Prof. Wang speaks very fluent and native English without an accent.  I have heard international students praised him for that.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm is very simple, in which most students get full marks.  If you want to ensure a good grade in this simple course, make sure to distinguish yourself in the final exam.

I got 93 out of 100 in total grade, and got A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Attending the tutorials is compulsory as there are quizzes almost every week. The questions are very similar to those provided in question pool, so if you want you can get yourself well prepared for the quizzes.

Given that it is a 4 credit course, I would say the workload is very light compared with most math courses, or most courses in this university.
